This game is addicting as hell. Music and weapon sounds are doing a great job slaugthering tons of mutants. Speaking of the weapons, the models are just great, the feeling is uncomparable to other FPS. Beside this, the game is just a hard challenge and needs tactical thinking which boosts the team play fun massively. "Graphic is not everyhing" is also matching description for this title, but don't dare to try it, it is worth the penny fella.

Decent game overall, but there's simply too large gaps between quests. I'm level 25, and already there's been several times where I had to grind XP to level up, before I could pick new quests. Right now, the next quests available are at the 30+ side. A 1-2 level gap would be fine, but 4+ level gap? That's simply insane. Completely ruins the fun.

I'm not good at writing reviews, but it feels criminal to love a game this much and not leave a positive review on it, so here's' a simple pros/cons list

Pros:
+Great soundtrack
+Weapons feel powerful and satisfying to fire (a feature somewhat lacking in KF2, in my opinion)
+Gritty, sinister 'apocalyptic' atmosphere to the maps, as opposed to the oddly clean, shiny and futuristic feel of KF2
+Full of personality
+Fast-paced
+Challenging, assuming you're not playing on lower difficulties. Not a hand-holding game.
+Many different weapons and perks to try
+Easy to sink countless hours into without it becoming 'stale' or 'old' (somewhat subjective)
+Many different official and community maps
+Not at all demanding and can be played on low-end systems, but at the same time, the graphics really aren't bad for a 2009 game

Cons:
-Likely to become less active with KF2 being out
-Progressing in perks can feel grindy at times, but is well worth the effort
-Very minor bugs exist

Overall, Killing Floor is still vastly superior to KF2 (though KF2 is not a bad game by any means), and is well worth the money for anyone who enjoys co-op survival or horde shooters.

Killing Floor - это когда весело

Killing Floor is a first person shooter, where you run around killing hordes of zombies and various other mutated creatures.

The mutants include one which looks just like the Boomer (of the "special infected" class of characters) from Left 4 Dead, and another which acts in a similar fashion to the Hunter from L4D.

However, Left 4 Dead came out in 2008, and Killing Floor was released as an Unreal Tournament mod in 2005 (prior to its retail release in 2009), so there is a time cross-over - it would be interesting to know which of the games included the Boomer-style character class first.

As Killing Floor 2 was released on Steam in November 2016, with a full retail price of $29.99 (why don't we just say $30), I was a bit surprised to find that Killing Floor was still being sold for $20, which I think is a bit over-priced; if you compare Killing Floor to a game like Battlefield (3, 4, or 1), then you can see that Killing Floor is quite dated - I would suggest that it should be sold for $5 or $10; if Killing Floor 2 takes away a lot of its player base, then Killing Floor may yet be reduced to a more reasonable price.

I should note that I played this with a two-day guest pass, so I haven't played the game as much as I would have liked. If the price comes down, I wouldn't mind buying it.
[Update: A few days after I wrote this review, Steam put it on sale for $4.99, so I jumped right in and bought it at that more reasonable price.]

Putting aside my comments about its cost, Killing Floor is a bit of shooting fun, so - if you are into FPS games - try it out!

Very good FPS shooter game. Recommended for all who got bored from L4D2 or enjoying fast paced FPS games.

+There's different perks, for example: Sharpshooter, Firebug, Support Specialist, Commando...
+There's LOTS OF different weapons! 10 times more than L4D2 has.
+The game has amazing official and player-made maps, even though they are generally non-objective / free roam maps, they won't make you bored.

-"Zeds" feel a bit alien-ish more than human eating zombies.
-Graphics and physics are not as good as L4D2.

For overall, the game is amazing even it is 7 years old.

A great game if you enjoy shooting up zombies' heads.

Incredibly easy to get the hang of, yet still manages to be super fun and enthralling. Story is basically non-existent, but who cares when you get to dual-wield revolvers and blast horrific abominations' heads off in slow motion? Also have to point out the kickass heavy metal soundtrack that ties in oh so well with the game play (honestly one of my favorite aspects).
In short, it's great fun, and I doubt you would regret buying it. Unless you don't enjoy horde based games, that is.

I think I'll go with a Q&A approach to this...

Q. Isn't this game just a bunch of zombies in co-op, coming at you in waves? There are a lot of these games already! How's it different?
A. Well, this game has a better pedigree than many. For me, a huge appeal of the game is the fun variety of maps. Sickening green laboratory, trashed office building by night, post-apocalyptic London streets, late afternoon forest with underground bunker tunnels, snowy military base, highway with grassy hills, and the list just goes on and on. Few games have so much quality map variety. If map variety is your thing, that aspect of this game may really appeal to you. Beyond the maps, the guns themselves "feel" really good to use, and that's not something I say often in games. The developers put a lot of is a lot of attention to how powerful certain guns feel to fire, the usefulness of each, and the game's economy.

Q. Economy? What are you talking about?
A. You get money in the game for each kill, and between waves, you can spend that money at a trader/shop. Granted, you need to either head toward the trader before killing the last enemy, because it can be a long haul, or run fast and hope you get there in time to peruse the store's goods. At the trader, you can purchase more ammo, new guns, sell guns, and buy body armor and grenades. Each difficulty gives you less money per kill, the harder the difficulty is set...which can sometimes feel a little ruthless, but if you want a challenge, that's the way to do it. Buying new weapons gives a feeling of progress throughout a round (one "game" of Killing Floor) and encourages participating to get more kills. Team mates can also toss cash to one another to help each other out, and there's a surprising amount of this cooperation despite playing with random people (probably because having a weak party member means less help against the horde!).

Q. It's all zombies, though, right? Boring!
A. Not exactly. Kinda? You have very zombie-like enemies, which are easy to kill, cloaking enemies that flicker in and out of view, enemies who have lights than change color and they then run at you to kill you, enemies who amble toward you then run full speed after taking a certain amount of damage, enemies that crawl on the ground and leap at you, and several more times, along with a boss who has a rocket launcher, a minigun, a cloaking device, and he can run away and heal. So no, not just zombie-ish enemies. You could draw comparisons, but there is a lot of great wave-based horde combat in this game.

Q. Is there really any story to the game itself? Not like...comics or videos online, but actual story happening in the game?
A. No. I love story, but there is none to find in the game. This game is a black hole as far as story/plot is concerned.

Q. Is there any progress in between rounds/games of Killing Floor? Like...does anything carry over so I have a feeling of progress/accomplishing something aside from achievements?
A. Actually, yes. Each "perk" (character class, like sharpshooter, firebug, demolitions, etc.) starts at Level 0 and levels up to...I wanna say 6 was the max? Anyway, leveling up takes quite a long time, but you get bonuses to various things like your damage with certain weapons each time you level, and discounts on buying certain weapons from the trader, if my memory serves. Maxing out all the classes will take a long time and got really old for me, but it does give you some sense of progress, if that's important to you.

Q. Is this game difficult?
A. Unlike some games, Killing Floor has multiple difficulties, and each changes how tough enemies are, money accrual rates, time to get to the trader between waves, etc. When you first start out, even on lower difficulties, you can get your butt kicked pretty well and good if you "go Rambo." Going Rambo is the easiest way to die in this game, regardless of the difficulty you play on, or even if you get pretty decent at the game. I'm sure there are a few people who can pull it off, but for the most part, you're going to die if you do it.

Q. Um...excuse me, what's "going Rambo?"
A. Oh! Sorry. Yeah, this is a co-op game, right? The best way to play it is to either meet up at one area and only spread out just a teensy bit to fend off various areas enemies wander in from, regularly taking a look to see if your buddies need a little help. Y'know, because it's co-op and that's kinda the idea. However, "going Rambo" is when someone decides "Wow, I wanna go run off all by myself because [reason]! I'll be fine. :D" If that's a new player, they are so dead. Experienced player? Toss a coin, it's rough. Like I said, I sure some great players can pull it off, but to be a good team player and not risk losing all your stuff, you'll want to stick together.

Q. Wait, losing all my stuff? Wha?
A. If you die, you can only respawn when the wave is over, and you spawn in without any weapons you bought at the trader. Whatever was in your hands when you died will be on the ground where you or your team mates can pick it up. So if you spent all the money you had on a new gun and you died while holding a crappy pistol, you just lost that fancy gun. In this fashion, you can pretty much be ruined if you and/or your team mates die on higher difficulties and have to respawn but lost pricey guns in the process, because money is so tight and the game is treating you like you have the best gear you could possibly have...even though you totally don't thanks to losing the guns and money.

Q. There's a Killing Floor 2. Should I just buy it instead?
A. As of right now? Probably not. It's been a few months since I played Killing Floor 2, and honestly, it does not yet have the map variety, well-balanced and complete sets of perks, and overall good feel of Killing Floor. Later, it might be better, but for now, you can get Killing Floor either in Humble Bundle bundles for cheap, or on Steam sales for like five bucks or less. I would certainly recommend it for that if you like cooperative, wave-based shooters with tons of map variety.

British/10

Ótimo jogo cooperativo, um dos melhores que já joguei em estilo FPS.

- Objetivo simples: Sobreviver a hordas de inimigos. Parece estranho,  mas é o que mais atrai no jogo.
- Não há mira fixa, no início é ruim, mas com o tempo, percebe que é divertido, além de ser um bom treinamento.
- Trabalho em equipe é essencial.

Pontos negativos:

- Algumas classes são muito difíceis de subir de nível, pois o sistema de compra de armas é um tanto absurdo, além de alguns requesitos apelões.
- Problema em rodar o jogo usando o Windows 10 (na época que testei neste sistema).
Killing Floor is one of those rare games you never really stop playing. No matter how long you stay away you'll always come back. This game definitely deserves The “Test of Time” Award!

It's been a few years now since Killing Floor 2 swept the original audience away, and what can I say?

Boot up Killing Floor and you'll find a few servers with fewer people still. Most players are veterans who frequented this game in its prime and stuck around when everyone else moved on to the sequel.

Compared to KF2, the original is slower, with a higher emphasis on tactical, disciplined play. At the highest level, there is next to no room for error.

What KF lacks in polish, it makes up for in charm. It captures something that KF2 can't even touch, which isn't to say it's a better game. Buy Killing Floor to get a piece of history, or for a great game at low cost and low requirements, or for a charming old-time experience.

Killing Floor 2 is great, but it's not a replacement for the first.
